mcqs.question: Which CSS keyword is used to import one stylesheet into another?
mcqs.explanation: The `@import` keyword is used to import one CSS file into another.

mcqs.question: What is the correct syntax for importing a CSS file named `theme.css`?
Where should the `@import` statement be placed in a CSS file?
options: At the very top, before all other styles
At the end of the file
mcqs.explanation: `@import` should be at the top of the CSS file, before any rules.

mcqs.question: Which is a potential drawback of using `@import` to include CSS files?
options: It makes code harder to read
It can slow down page load
It doesn't work in any browser
It is only used for HTML files
mcqs.explanation: `@import` can delay the loading of CSS, as files are fetched after the main CSS is loaded.

mcqs.question: Which is the most efficient way to include multiple CSS files?
mcqs.explanation: Using multiple `<link>` tags is more efficient because browsers load them in parallel.

mcqs.question: What happens if you use `@import` inside a CSS rule?
options: The rule will work as normal
It will import the CSS correctly
mcqs.explanation: `@import` must be placed at the top of the file, outside of any CSS rule.

mcqs.question: Which of the following is NOT a valid way to import a CSS file?
How does `@import` affect CSS specificity?
options: Imported styles always have higher specificity
Imported styles follow the normal cascade and specificity rules
Imported styles override inline styles by default
mcqs.explanation: Imported styles follow normal cascade and specificity rules.

mcqs.question: Which is a correct way to import a Google Font in your CSS?
mcqs.explanation: Google Fonts provides a URL to import with `@import url('...');`.

mcqs.question: Can you use media queries with the `@import` rule?
mcqs.explanation: You can use media queries after the file path, e.g., `@import url('print.css') print;`.

mcqs.question: Which of these is true about `@import` and browser support?
options: It is supported by all modern browsers
It is only supported in Chrome
It is not supported in any browser
mcqs.explanation: `@import` is supported by all modern browsers, but has performance drawbacks.

mcqs.question: What is the difference between `@import` and `<link>` for CSS files?
options: `@import` loads files after the main CSS, `<link>` loads in parallel
`@import` can only be used in HTML
`<link>` can only be used for internal CSS
mcqs.explanation: `@import` loads files sequentially, which can delay rendering. `<link>` allows for parallel loading.

mcqs.question: Which is the correct way to import a CSS file for print media only?
mcqs.explanation: `@import url('print.css') print;` imports the stylesheet only for print media.

mcqs.question: What will happen if you try to import a non-existent CSS file?
options: The rest of the CSS will not load
Only the import will fail; the rest of the CSS works
mcqs.explanation: If the imported file is missing, only that import fails; the rest of your CSS will still be applied.

mcqs.question: Which of these is a best practice for large projects?
options: Use multiple `@import` statements for every file
Combine CSS into fewer files and use `<link>` tags
Import CSS files in the HTML `<body>`
mcqs.explanation: Combining CSS files and using `<link>` tags improves performance and maintainability.
